head.title: Sorenstam Outshined By Winner And Wie

hedline.hl1: Sorenstam Outshined By Winner And Wie
hedline.hl2: Sorenstam Outshined in Kraft Nabisco Championship

abstract.p: Patricia Meunier-Lebouc wins Kraft Nabisco Championship (M)

block.p: There will surely be better days for Michelle Wie, who showed that she was 13.
There will also be better days for Annika Sorenstam, who showed again that she was vulnerable.
Patricia Meunier-Lebouc, a 30-year-old Frenchwoman, held off Annika Sorenstam by a stroke to capture the L.P.G.A's first major of the season.
There will surely be better days for Michelle Wie, who showed that she was 13.
There will also be better days for Annika Sorenstam, who showed again that she was vulnerable.
But there may never be a better day for Patricia Meunier-Lebouc, who showed that she could win a major championship against the best players in the world.
With a solid back nine at Mission Hills Country Club, Meunier-Lebouc held off Sorenstam by a stroke today to capture the Kraft Nabisco Championship, the L.P.G.A's first major of the season.
Meunier-Lebouc, a 30-year-old Frenchwoman, closed with a one-over-par 73 for a total of seven-under 281, edging Sorenstam, who shot a 71. The rookie Lorena Ochoa was third, two shots back.

Wie, an eighth-grader from Hawaii who seized the spotlight this weekend, faltered with a four-over 76 to finish at even par for the tournament, tying for ninth. Playing in the final group in her first appearance in a major, Wie managed to keep things together with an even-par 36 on the front, then gave away four shots on the back. Wie, who had only one birdie all day, three-putted Nos. 12, 14 and 16.
Meunier-Lebouc started the day with a three-stroke advantage, but was passed when Sorenstam birdied No. 12.

Sorenstam, the two-time defending champion, seemed poised to make it three straight. But her three-putt bogey on No. 13, coupled with Meunier-Lebouc's 18-foot birdie putt from the fringe, resulted in a two-shot swing that gave Meunier-Lebouc a lead she never relinquished.

She parred the next four holes while Sorenstam, who bogeyed No. 14, failed to apply pressure down the stretch for the second tournament in a row. She tied for third last week in Phoenix, finishing four strokes behind Se Ri Pak.
After signing her scorecard, Meunier-Lebouc, along with her husband, Antoine, and her caddie, took the traditional plunge into the greenside lake.
The triumph is her second since joining the L.P.G.A. Tour in 2001. She was also a member of the victorious 2000 European Solheim Cup team.

''I just can still not believe it, but I did it,'' said Meunier-Lebouc, who earned $240,000. ''That's why my husband came to me and said: 'You did it. You just did it.' And I said, 'Yes.' I felt so good.''
Sorenstam, who was unable to break 71 after opening the tournament with a 68, was a bit frustrated with her inability to make putts.

''Unfortunately, I made two mistakes on 13 and 14,'' said Sorenstam, who won 11 Tour events in 2002. ''After that I was just trying to chase her the last few holes. I tried all week and have not made a lot of putts. I've hit a lot of lips and sometimes at these tournaments, you need some good breaks.''

For Wie, who has been on her spring break, it was a week that she and many spectators will not soon forget. After making the cut with rounds of 72 and 74, she came through with a brilliant six-under 66 on Saturday, tying the lowest score for an amateur in an L.P.G.A. major. Remarkably, as she headed to the back nine, she still had a chance to win the tournament, trailing by three.
''I think I played pretty well all day,'' said Wie, whose father, B. J., was her caddie. ''I think I played extra well on the third day, so I was really happy about that score.''
The 6-foot Wie also picked up another admirer.
''She has a lot of talent,'' Sorenstam said. ''She has a wonderful swing. She has a great future ahead of her.''

Another with a great future is Ochoa, the clear favorite to be the Tour's rookie of the year. She was in excellent shape to win the tournament until she shot a 42 on the back nine on Saturday, putting her seven shots behind Meunier-Lebouc. But with a four-under 68, Ochoa, a native of Mexico, bounced back.
''I'm extremely happy with the way I finished,'' Ochoa, who birdied Nos. 16 and 17, said. ''This will give me a lot of confidence.''
But the day belonged to Meunier-Lebouc, whose previous victory came in last year's State Farm Classic.

''It's an achievement,'' she said. ''I think that's how you call it. I really work hard and give a lot to be able to be coming here, competing on the L.P.G.A. If it's my day, I deserve it. So if it's my day, I'll take it. It gives me even more motivation to work and just keep going.''
GOLF
